abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ozone Depleting
            Substances Phase-out Project for Philippines were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            global environment outcome was moderate; Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was
            also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: project duration. The project combined two
            operations in one over a 17-year period. While this approach
            may have had advantages from the point of view of
            bureaucratic processing, it also had disadvantages. Notably,
            closure of first phase when the investment sub-projects were
            completed would have allowed a formal valuation of the first
            phase implementation experience which could have contributed
            to second phase design. Furthermore, having been designed as
            part of an ongoing project rather than a self-standing new
            operation, second phase did not benefit from a formal World
            Bank appraisal, this might have uncovered some of the design
            weaknesses that plagued second phase implementation.
            Furthermore, due to the long duration of the project, the
            evaluation of the earlier implementation years was
            significantly constrained by staff changes in the relevant
            Government agencies and the Bank, and changes in the
            enterprises that benefitted from the Project. Monitoring
            outcomes vs. outputs. A limited number of the planned
            project outputs were achieved and contributed to the
            achievement of the Global Environment Objective (GEO) during
            second phase. The Philippines was reaching the objectives
            set for the project mainly due to factors external to the
            project, while a number of planned project outputs were
            either not being generated or poorly generated.
            Implementation progress monitoring. The project demonstrated
            that the Bank could have better assessed implementation
            progress. Voucher system design and implementation. The
            experience with the voucher scheme implementation under the
            project highlighted the need to make sure that financial and
            time costs for service shops' participation in the
            scheme are minimal, and a rigorous, adequately funded
            monitoring system is in place from the very beginning to
            ensure that no parties in the system engage in abuses, all
            eligible beneficiaries receive proper equipment and use them properly.
